When Venus did desend from heven above,</br>To vewe the earthe, which longe time she had lefte,</br>(For since Diana had destroyed hir love,</br>The woddes and feilds weare of hir sighte berefte;)</br>Itt was hir chaunc on Daymon for to finde,</br>Whos yealdinge thoughte hir beawtye rare did bynde.

This Daymon was prowde, envious, and untrewe,</br>Faythful to none, butt full of secrett spighte;</br>A servaunte farre unfitte where he did sue,</br>His tongue he framed to meritte what he mighte;</br>Which was with flatterye so fullye charmen,</br>That none could 'scape, but was by itt muche harmen.

A glorious minde, which made him hated moste,</br>Full of disdayne, thoughe none more base then he;</br>Of Venus favour often would he boste,</br>Who was not worthye her fayer eyes to see:</br>But longe he did nott in this triumphe dwell,</br>For Mars his jealowzye beganne to swell.

His wrathe was greate, revenge he soone did take,</br>Of this boulde gueste, who soughte, like Nero, fame;</br>He methamorfosed was, for Venus sake,</br>In water, to delaye his burning flame;</br>A runninge streame, yett never clensede from yll,</br>Where vertue ebbes, and mischiefe flowethe styll.

A moddye lake, a sinke of loathsome taste,</br>A pitte where snaks theire venome moste did hide;</br>A poysone stronge, to make all goodnes waste</br>The depthe of vice, that never could be tried:</br>Wher treason swimes, and all deceipte dothe dwell,</br>A water, worse than that which leads to hell!</br>
